oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Frame farmhouse
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Chimneys; Houses; Farmhouses; Porches; Wildflowers
Agriculture; Farmhouses
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Angled view of the front and side of an unidentified frame farmhouse. The house is a two-story I-house with a one-story ell. The frame is covered with weatherboard. There is a covered porch on the front facade of the house.

The central-hall cottage or I-house is a common example of vernacular architecture in Tennessee dwellings. Such homes date from the early nineteenth through the late twentieth centuries. The exterior was usually frame with gabled roofs and often had gable end chimneys. The interior consisted of a central hall with symmetrical rooms to either side.
